I want to use heart rate zones to guide my Hyrox training. How do I set them up and how do different training types map to different zones?

Heart rate zones are the best real-time feedback tool for Hyrox training — they tell you exactly which energy system you're targeting and whether you're hitting the right intensity. Here's how to set them up properly and apply them across your training.

**Step 1: Establish your max heart rate**

Forget the 220-age formula. It's inaccurate by ±10-12 bpm. Instead:

**Field test (preferred):** After a thorough warm-up, run 3 x 3 min at increasing intensity on a flat surface. The third interval should be absolute max effort for the final minute. The highest HR reading is your HRmax. Do this wearing a chest strap HR monitor — wrist monitors are unreliable at high intensities.

**Alternative:** Use the highest HR you've ever recorded during a race or all-out interval session. That's a reasonable proxy.

**Step 2: Set your zones**

| Zone | % HRmax | Name | Feel | RPE |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Zone 1 | 50-60% | Recovery | Very easy, barely elevated breathing | 2-3/10 |
| Zone 2 | 60-70% | Aerobic Base | Conversational, nasal breathing possible | 4-5/10 |
| Zone 3 | 70-80% | Tempo/Threshold | Comfortably hard, can speak in short sentences | 6-7/10 |
| Zone 4 | 80-90% | VO2max/Hard | Hard, labored breathing, can only say a few words | 8-9/10 |
| Zone 5 | 90-100% | Max Effort | All-out, unsustainable beyond 1-3 min | 10/10 |

For a 30-year-old with HRmax of 190: Zone 2 = 114-133 bpm, Zone 3 = 133-152 bpm, Zone 4 = 152-171 bpm.

**Step 3: Map training types to zones**

| Training Type | Target Zone | Duration | Hyrox Purpose |
|---|---|---|---|
| Easy/recovery runs | Zone 1-2 | 45-90 min | Aerobic base, fat oxidation, lactate clearance capacity |
| Long runs | Zone 2 (mostly) | 60-90 min | Capillarization, mitochondrial density, cardiac efficiency |
| Tempo runs | Zone 3 | 20-40 min continuous | Lactate threshold improvement, race-pace running |
| VO2max intervals (4x4) | Zone 4-5 | 4 min work, 3 min rest | Max aerobic capacity, oxygen utilization |
| Hyrox station work | Zone 4-5 (during), Zone 3 (between) | Variable | Glycolytic capacity, station-specific muscular endurance |
| Compromised running | Zone 3-4 (settling from Zone 5) | 400m-1km post-station | Lactate clearance while moving, race simulation |
| Strength training | Zone 2-3 (variable) | 45-60 min | Not a reliable HR guide — use RPE and load % instead |

**Step 4: Apply zones to your weekly Hyrox plan**

A well-structured Hyrox week should follow the polarized training model — approximately 80% of training time in Zone 1-2, 20% in Zone 4-5, and minimal time in Zone 3 (the "no man's land" where you're too hard for recovery but too easy for max adaptation).

| Day | Session | Zone Focus |
|---|---|---|
| Monday AM | Easy run | Zone 2 |
| Monday PM | HIIT (stations + runs) | Zone 4-5 (stations), Zone 3-4 (runs) |
| Tuesday | Strength | N/A (use load %) |
| Wednesday | Tempo run | Zone 3 |
| Thursday | HIIT (Hyrox-specific) | Zone 4-5 |
| Friday | Easy run | Zone 1-2 |
| Saturday | Long run | Zone 2 |
| Sunday | Rest | Zone 0 |

**Race day zone targets:**
During the actual Hyrox race, Brandt et al. (2025) data shows you'll be at 80%+ HRmax (Zone 4+) for about 80% of the race. Your 1km runs should target Zone 3-4 (70-85% HRmax). Stations will push you to Zone 4-5 involuntarily. The goal is to keep your running segments as LOW in zone as possible while maintaining pace — that's pacing discipline.

**Nutrition connection:** Zone 2 work is primarily fat-fueled and doesn't require intra-workout carbs. Zone 4-5 work is glycogen-dependent. On days with significant Zone 4-5 training (HIIT sessions, simulations), increase carb intake to 6-8 g/kg and consider intra-workout carbs if the session exceeds 60 minutes.

How should I pace the 8 running segments in a Hyrox race? Should I try to run them all at the same speed?

No — even pacing across all 8 kilometers is a theoretical ideal that doesn't account for the reality of station-induced fatigue. Here's a pacing strategy built on both race data and exercise physiology.

**The data on how runners actually pace Hyrox:**

Analysis from hyroxdatalab.com and Roxlyfe.com shows consistent patterns:
- Runs 1-2 are typically the fastest (fresh legs, adrenaline)
- Runs 3-4 show the biggest slowdown (after sled push/pull — the most glycolytic stations)
- Runs 5-6 stabilize (after rowing and farmers carry — less metabolically demanding)
- Run 7 dips again (after sandbag lunges — quad fatigue)
- Run 8 is variable (some athletes dig deep, others are destroyed by cumulative fatigue)

Elite athletes like Roncevic maintain remarkably consistent splits — less than 5 seconds variance across all 8 runs. Recreational athletes often see 30-60 second variance, with Runs 3-4 being the slowest.

**Your pacing strategy by run:**

Assuming a target average of 4:40/km (which yields ~37:20 total running time):

| Run | Target Pace | Strategy | Why |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Run 1** | 4:35/km | Slightly faster — you're fresh | Bank a small buffer, but don't sprint. Control the adrenaline. |
| **Run 2** | 4:40/km | Goal pace | SkiErg fatigue is manageable — mostly upper body |
| **Run 3** | 4:50/km | Allow 10 sec slow | Post-sled push. Lactate is 7-8 mmol/L. First 200m will be ugly — jog at 5:30/km, then build to 4:40 by 400m. |
| **Run 4** | 4:50/km | Allow 10 sec slow | Post-sled pull. Similar lactate burden. Same 200m build strategy. |
| **Run 5** | 4:40/km | Back to goal pace | Post-BBJ. Less glycolytic than sleds. Your legs will feel better. |
| **Run 6** | 4:40/km | Goal pace | Post-rowing. Full-body fatigue but less leg-specific. |
| **Run 7** | 4:45/km | Slight slowdown allowed | Post-farmers carry. Grip fatigue doesn't affect running, but cumulative fatigue is building. |
| **Run 8** | 4:35/km | Fastest finish possible | Post-sandbag lunges. Quads are burning. But this is the LAST RUN. Empty the tank. Negative split if you can. |

**Total estimated running time: ~37:20-37:40**

**The critical mental model:**

Think of your 8 runs in three blocks:
- **Block 1 (Runs 1-2):** Set the tone. Controlled, confident, at or slightly below target pace.
- **Block 2 (Runs 3-5):** Survive. This is where races are lost, not won. Allow the post-sled runs to be slower. Don't panic when Run 3 feels awful. Use the 200m build strategy.
- **Block 3 (Runs 6-8):** Attack. By Run 6, the hardest stations are behind you. If you've paced correctly, you have glycogen left. This is where disciplined athletes pass those who went out too fast.

**Pacing tools:**
- Write your per-km targets on your arm with permanent marker. Reference it at the start of each run.
- Use your GPS watch but set it to show current pace, not average pace. You need real-time feedback.
- Practice pacing in training: run 8 x 1km at your target pace with 3-min rest. If your splits vary by more than 8 seconds, your internal pacing clock needs calibration.

**Nutrition connection:** Take a gel during Run 3 or Run 6. These are the moments when blood glucose support is most impactful — you're at the deepest glycogen deficit points after the most demanding stations. A 25g carb gel during Run 6 can be the difference between maintaining pace on Runs 7-8 or collapsing.

The athletes who win Hyrox aren't the fastest on any single run. They're the most consistent across all eight.

What's the minimum effective dose for strength training during a Hyrox program? I don't want to spend more time in the gym than I need to.

I love this question because most Hyrox athletes spend too much time on strength and not enough on the aerobic work that actually drives race performance. Here's the evidence-based minimum effective dose for strength maintenance during a 16-week Hyrox program.

**The key insight from research:**
Brandt et al. (2025) found that strength metrics (grip strength, muscle mass) did NOT significantly correlate with Hyrox finish time. VO2max and endurance volume were the strongest predictors. This tells us that once you can handle race-weight loads competently, additional strength is a game of diminishing returns.

**Your strength threshold for Men's Open:**
- Sled push: Can you push 152kg for 50m without stopping? If yes, you have enough.
- Sled pull: Can you pull 103kg for 50m without losing tension? If yes, you're fine.
- Farmers carry: Can you hold 2x24kg for 2+ minutes? If yes, maintenance only.
- Wall balls: Can you do 100 reps at 6kg without technique breakdown? That's muscular endurance, not strength.

If you meet these thresholds, here's your minimum effective dose:

**1 session per week (during Phases 2-4), 45 minutes:**

| Exercise | Sets x Reps | Load | Rest | Purpose |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Back Squat | 3 x 4 | 80-85% 1RM | 3 min | Lower body neural maintenance |
| Deadlift or RDL | 3 x 3 | 82-87% 1RM | 3 min | Posterior chain, sled pull transfer |
| Barbell Row | 3 x 6 | 75% 1RM | 2 min | Upper back, sled pull, rowing |
| Strict Press | 3 x 6 | 70% 1RM | 2 min | Shoulder endurance for wall balls, SkiErg |
| Pull-ups | 2 x max | Bodyweight | 2 min | General upper body strength |

That's 5 exercises, 14 working sets, ~45 minutes including warm-up. Done.

**During Phase 1 (General Prep), do 2 sessions per week** — one lower body focused, one upper body. You're still building the strength base and establishing movement patterns. But by Phase 2, you've earned the right to consolidate to 1 session.

**Why this works:**

Galpin's research and the broader concurrent training literature show that strength *maintenance* requires far less volume than strength *development*. As few as 1-2 heavy sessions per week with 6-10 total sets can preserve 90%+ of maximal strength for 12+ weeks. The key is keeping intensity high (80%+ 1RM) while reducing volume (fewer sets). Neural adaptations — the ability to recruit motor units efficiently — are maintained with minimal volume at high loads.

**What gets cut and what stays:**

| Keep | Cut |
|---|---|
| Heavy compound lifts (squat, deadlift, press) | Isolation exercises (curls, extensions, lateral raises) |
| Low reps, high load (3-6 reps at 80%+) | Hypertrophy work (10-15 reps at 65%) |
| 3-5 min rest between heavy sets | Supersets, drop sets, giant sets |
| Functional patterns (squat, hinge, press, pull) | Machine work, cable work |

**The freed-up time goes directly to:**
- An additional easy run (50-60 min Zone 2)
- A Hyrox-specific HIIT session with compromised running
- Active recovery (walk, foam roll, mobility)

All three of those options contribute more to your Hyrox finish time than a second strength session per week. Spend your training time where the return on investment is highest.

Should I train burpee broad jumps differently in the early weeks vs the later weeks of my program? How does progression work for such a weird movement?

Burpee broad jumps are the most underrated station in Hyrox training. Most athletes barely practice them, and it costs them 1-2 minutes on race day. The movement IS weird — it's a hybrid of explosive power, coordination, and pacing discipline across 80 meters. Here's how to progressively build it across a 16-week plan.

**Understanding the demand:**
80m of burpee broad jumps takes approximately 3-5 minutes and covers about 55-70 individual reps (depending on your jump distance of ~1.1-1.5m per rep). The energy system is glycolytic dominant with significant oxidative contribution — it's a repeated explosive effort sustained over several minutes. Galpin would classify this as a mix of power (#3), muscular endurance (#6), and anaerobic capacity (#7).

**Phase 1: General Prep (Weeks 1-4) — Movement Skill**

Priority: Learn the step-up method and establish consistent jump distance.

- **Volume:** 40m per session, 2x per week (within HIIT sessions)
- **Technique focus:** Use the step-up method — step back into plank, step feet to hands, jump. This saves ~15-20% energy vs the traditional chest-to-floor burpee while being fully legal in Hyrox rules.
- **Jump distance tracking:** Measure your average jump distance. Target 1.2-1.4m per rep for Men's Open.
- **RPE:** 5-6. This is skill practice, not conditioning.
- **Recovery connection:** BBJ is hard on the wrists and hip flexors. After BBJ training, spend 2 minutes on wrist stretches and hip flexor stretches. Consider collagen peptides (10-15g + 50mg Vitamin C, 30-60 min before training) if wrist soreness develops — Shaw et al. (2017) showed potential tendon health benefits.

**Phase 2: Specific Prep (Weeks 5-8) — Volume Accumulation**

Priority: Build toward race distance under moderate fatigue.

- **Volume:** 60m per session, 2-3x per week
- **Coupling:** Add compromised running — 16m BBJ → 400m run → 16m BBJ → 400m run → 16m BBJ → 400m run. This is HIIT #6 in the library. Track both BBJ time and run splits.
- **Pacing:** Establish your per-rep cadence. If each rep takes 4-5 seconds and you jump 1.3m, 80m takes about 62 reps x 4.5 sec = ~4:39. You need to maintain this cadence from rep 1 to rep 62.
- **RPE:** 7-8. Push the intensity but maintain technique.

**Phase 3: Competition Prep (Weeks 9-12) — Race Specificity**

Priority: Full 80m at race speed, practiced after Run 4 equivalent.

- **Volume:** 80m (full race distance) in at least 2 sessions per week
- **Context:** Perform BBJ after a 1km run at race pace AND after sled pull work. This simulates the race sequence (Run 4 → BBJ). Your quads will be pre-fatigued from sled work, exactly like race day.
- **Time target:** Sub-4 minutes for 80m is competitive for Men's Open. Track this weekly.
- **RPE:** 8-9. This should feel uncomfortable. If it's easy at 80m, you're not pushing hard enough.

**Phase 4: Taper (Weeks 13-16) — Maintenance**

- **Volume:** 40m per session, 1-2x per week
- **Intensity:** 85-90% of race pace. Stay sharp but don't create fatigue.
- **Purpose:** Maintain the motor pattern and pacing discipline without accumulating training stress.

**Nutrition timing for BBJ-heavy sessions:**
BBJ sessions are glycogen-hungry — repeated explosive efforts burn through glycolytic stores fast. Ensure 60-80g of carbs in your pre-session meal (1-2 hours before). On days with BBJ + compromised running, total carb intake should be at the high end: 7-8 g/kg.

The athletes who get burned by BBJ on race day are the ones who never practiced it beyond 20m in training. Don't be that athlete. Progressive overload applies to weird movements too.

Five days is more than enough for Hyrox preparation — you just need to be ruthlessly efficient with session design. Here's how to structure it during the key Specific Prep phase (Weeks 5-8).

**The 5-day template:**

| Day | Session | Duration | Focus |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Monday** | AM: Easy Run / PM: HIIT | 50 min + 50 min | Zone 2 aerobic base + Hyrox station work |
| **Tuesday** | Strength + Short Run | 55 min + 25 min | Heavy compounds + 2.5-mile compromised run |

**Weekly totals:**

- HIIT: 2 sessions
- Strength: 1 session (minimum effective dose)
- Two full rest days for recovery

**The secret to making 5 days work: session stacking.**

Instead of dedicating separate days to running AND strength AND HIIT, you combine:

1. **Monday double:** AM easy run (pure aerobic, Zone 2) + PM HIIT (stations + transition work). The 6-hour gap between sessions minimizes the AMPK-mTOR interference effect. If you can't do two-a-days, make Monday a single 90-min session: 30-min easy run → transition straight into 50-min HIIT with stations.

2. **Tuesday strength + run:** After your heavy lifting (squat, deadlift, press — 45 min), immediately run 2.5 miles at easy pace. This is "compromised running" — your legs are fatigued from the lifts, which simulates running after Hyrox stations. Two training adaptations in one session.

3. **Thursday HIIT with built-in running:** Your HIIT sessions should already include 400m-1km runs between stations. A well-designed HIIT session with 4-5 station movements and 4-5 run segments gives you 2-3 miles of running within the session itself.

**Nutrition is more critical on a 5-day schedule:**

With only 5 training days, each session carries more weight. You can't afford a bad session because there's no sixth day to make it up. This means:
- Training day calories at maintenance or slight surplus: 3,300-3,800 kcal
- Carbs at 6-8 g/kg on training days: 490-656g for an 82kg athlete
- Protein at 2.0 g/kg daily without exception: 164g
- Rest day calories can be slightly reduced: 2,700-3,000 kcal with 4-5 g/kg carbs

**Sleep becomes non-negotiable:** With less total training volume, each session's quality matters more. And quality depends on recovery. Target 8-9 hours per night. If you're sleeping 6-7 hours, you're effectively turning a 5-day plan into a 3-day plan because you're not recovering between sessions.

**Phase adjustments for 5 days:**
- Phase 1 (Weeks 1-4): Add a second strength session by replacing one HIIT session. You're building the base.
- Phase 3 (Weeks 9-12): Add a third HIIT session by dropping the dedicated strength day (combine strength movements into HIIT warm-ups).
- Phase 4 (Taper): Drop to 4 days. Reduce everything by 20-30%.

Five days with high-quality sessions, proper nutrition, and adequate sleep will produce a better Hyrox result than 7 poorly recovered, under-fueled training days.

What's the Roxzone and why does it matter for training? I keep hearing people lose time there.

The Roxzone is the most underestimated time sink in Hyrox, and it's where undisciplined athletes hemorrhage minutes without realizing it. Let me explain what it is, the rules, and how to train for it.

**What the Roxzone is:**
The Roxzone is the central transition area inside the running track where all 8 workout stations are set up. Every time you finish a 1km run, you enter the Roxzone through an IN arch, move to your next station, complete the station, then exit through the OUT arch to start your next run. You pass through the Roxzone 16 times in a race (8 entries, 8 exits).

**How much time it costs:**

| Athlete Level | Total Roxzone Time | % of Race |
|---|---|---|
| Elite men (~59 min) | ~2:54 | 5% |
| Average men (~90 min) | ~6:58 | 8% |
| Slower competitors (~120 min) | ~10:00+ | 8-10% |

The difference between elite and average Roxzone time is 4+ minutes. That's time spent walking, standing around, catching your breath, or getting lost — NOT doing the actual work.

**The rules that can cost you penalties:**

| Rule | Penalty |
|---|---|
| Enter via OUT arch or exit via IN arch | 2-min penalty per infringement |
| Outside assistance (food, drink, or help from spectators) | 3-min penalty |
| Pour water over your body (water is for drinking only) | 2-min penalty |
| Litter (gel wrappers, cups on floor) | 2-min penalty |
| Spit or clear nose on floor | 2-min penalty |
| Use chalk at stations other than sled pull and farmers carry | 2-min penalty |

Those penalties are devastating. A single wrong-arch entry costs you more time than most station improvements would save.

**How to train for fast Roxzone transitions:**

1. **Practice immediate movement after stations.** In your HIIT training, NEVER sit or stand still after completing a station. Finish your sled push, immediately walk to where a run would start, and begin jogging. This habit eliminates the 10-30 seconds most athletes waste catching their breath at the station.

2. **Hinshaw's active recovery principle:** The Roxzone walk/jog from station to track IS your recovery. Move at a deliberate, purposeful pace — fast walk or slow jog. Your slow-twitch fibers are actively clearing lactate while you move. Standing still shuts this process down.

3. **Simulate transitions in training:** In your race simulations, add 100m of walking/jogging between each station and each run. This mimics the Roxzone distance (~800m-1km total across the race). Time these transitions — your goal is less than 30 seconds per Roxzone pass-through.

4. **Plan your gel/water intake during Roxzone transitions.** There are aid stations in the Roxzone. Know which pass-throughs you'll use for hydration (after Stations 2 and 5 are optimal). Practice grabbing a cup, drinking while walking, and disposing of it in a bin (no littering!) during training simulations.

5. **Know the arch system.** IN arch = entering Roxzone from the running track. OUT arch = exiting Roxzone to the running track. Always enter through IN, exit through OUT. It sounds obvious, but in the chaos of a race with hundreds of athletes, people get confused — especially in Runs 5-8 when cognitive function is impaired by fatigue.

**The connection to race-day nutrition and pacing:**
Roxzone time balloons when athletes are under-fueled or have gone out too fast. If you're in glycogen debt by Station 5, you'll naturally slow down in the Roxzone because your body is desperately trying to recover. Proper fueling (gels during runs 3 and 6) and conservative pacing in the first half keep your Roxzone transitions fast and deliberate in the second half.

Train your transitions the same way you train your stations. The minutes you save in the Roxzone are the easiest minutes in Hyrox to improve.

How should my training change if I'm doing Hyrox Doubles instead of Singles?

Doubles changes the game significantly — the station demands double but the running demand stays identical. Here's how to adjust your training.

**What changes in Doubles:**

| Aspect | Singles | Doubles |
|---|---|---|
| Running | 8 x 1km solo | 8 x 1km together (must stay together, 1-min penalty per separation) |
| SkiErg | 1,000m | 2,000m total (split however you want) |
| Sled Push | 4 x 12.5m | 8 x 12.5m total |
| Sled Pull | 4 x 12.5m | 8 x 12.5m total |
| BBJ | 80m | 160m total |
| Rowing | 1,000m | 2,000m total |
| Farmers Carry | 200m | 400m total |
| Sandbag Lunges | 100m | 200m total |
| Wall Balls | 100 reps | 200 reps total |

**The critical rule:** Only one partner works at a time at each station. The other waits. So while total station work doubles, YOU only do your share — and how you split it is strategic.

**Training adjustments for Doubles:**

**1. Running is STILL king.**
Both partners run every kilometer together. The running demand is identical to Singles. If anything, running fitness matters MORE in Doubles because slower partners force faster partners to hold back. Train your running the same as Singles — 35-40 mpw, Zone 2 base, tempo runs, intervals.

The one addition: practice running at your PARTNER'S pace. If they're slower, you need to learn to run at their tempo without getting frustrated or letting your form deteriorate. If they're faster, you need to push to stay with them. Do at least 2 training runs per week together.

**2. Station splitting strategy drives training focus.**
The optimal split depends on each partner's strengths. Common strategies:

| Strategy | How | Best When |
|---|---|---|
| 50/50 even split | Each partner does exactly half of every station | Partners are equally fit |
| Strength/Endurance split | Stronger partner takes more sled, carry; faster partner takes more erg, BBJ, lunges | One partner is stronger, the other more endurance-oriented |
| Fatigue rotation | Partner A does Stations 1-2-5-6, Partner B does 3-4-7-8 | Alternating heavy and light stations to manage fatigue |

**Train your specific split.** If you're the sled-heavy partner, your training should overemphasize sled push/pull volume — 8x12.5m instead of 4x12.5m per training session. If you're the wall ball partner, practice sets of 100+ reps at race weight.

**3. Doubled station volume means nutrition demands increase for stations.**
If you're the partner handling more station work, your glycolytic demand is higher. Increase intra-workout carbs accordingly — 40-70g per hour instead of 30-60g. Your partner's needs may differ based on their split.

**4. Communication training.**
This sounds soft, but it's crucial. Practice:
- Handoff signals at stations ("GO" when you're done, partner starts immediately)
- Running pace negotiation (who sets the pace on each run)
- Mid-race adjustment (if one partner is fading, how do you redistribute station work)

Do at least 2-3 full Doubles simulations together before race day. Time each partner's station splits separately and optimize the distribution based on real data, not assumptions.

**5. The Roxzone is harder in Doubles.**
Both athletes must navigate the transition together. You lose an extra 5-10 seconds per Roxzone pass-through compared to Singles because of coordination overhead. Practice moving through transitions as a pair — the waiting partner should be walking to the station exit while the working partner finishes.

Doubles is not "Singles made easier." It's a different race that rewards partner coordination, smart splitting, and synchronized pacing. Train together at least 30% of your sessions in the final 8 weeks.

You're not doing anything wrong per se — you're doing something *incomplete*. This is an extremely common issue called the "Zone 2 trap," and it happens when athletes spend 100% of their training time on aerobic base without any high-intensity work to develop the upper end of their fitness.

**The physiology of what's happening:**

Your Zone 2 training has successfully built:
- Increased mitochondrial density (more energy factories per muscle cell)
- Better fat oxidation (you burn fat more efficiently at low intensities)
- Improved capillarization (better oxygen delivery)
- Greater cardiac stroke volume (more blood per heartbeat)

This is the foundation — and it's valuable. But here's what Zone 2 does NOT develop:
- **VO2max (your ceiling).** Zone 2 operates at 60-70% HRmax. VO2max improves primarily from intervals at 85-95% HRmax (Zone 4-5). Your ceiling hasn't moved, so race-pace effort still requires a high percentage of your max capacity.
- **Lactate threshold.** The intensity above which lactate accumulates faster than you clear it. This improves primarily through tempo runs at 80-88% HRmax (Zone 3). If your threshold is low, race pace pushes you above it and you accumulate lactate rapidly.
- **Running economy at speed.** The neuromuscular patterns for fast running are different from slow running. You need some high-speed work to train your nervous system to recruit motor units efficiently at race pace.

**The polarized training model — what you're missing:**

Elite endurance athletes follow an 80/20 intensity distribution:
- 80% of training time in Zone 1-2 (easy)
- 0-5% in Zone 3 (threshold — the "gray zone")
- 15-20% in Zone 4-5 (hard intervals)

If you're doing 100% Zone 2, you're missing that critical 20% of high-intensity work. That 20% is where your VO2max and lactate threshold improve — the two things that make race pace feel easier.

**What to add immediately (without reducing your Zone 2 volume):**

**1. One VO2max interval session per week:**
Norwegian 4x4 protocol: 4 min at 85-90% HRmax → 3 min easy jog → repeat 4 times. This is the gold standard for VO2max development. Your heart rate during the work intervals should be in Zone 4-5 by minute 2-3. If it's not, you're not going hard enough.

**2. One tempo/threshold session per week:**
Options (alternate weekly):
- 3 miles at half-marathon pace (continuous tempo)
- 3 x 10 min at lactate threshold pace with 3-min jog recovery (cruise intervals)
- Progressive run: 5 miles, building from Zone 2 to Zone 3 over the run, last mile at threshold

**3. Weekly strides (add to 2 easy runs):**
4 x 100m at mile pace with full walk-back recovery. Takes 10 minutes, adds zero fatigue, and trains neuromuscular recruitment patterns at high speed.

**Your revised weekly structure:**

| Day | Before (all Zone 2) | After (polarized) |
|---|---|---|
| Monday | Easy run 60 min | Easy run 50 min + HIIT PM |
| Tuesday | Easy run 50 min | Strength |
| Wednesday | Easy run 60 min | Tempo/threshold run 55 min |
| Thursday | Easy run 50 min | HIIT (Hyrox stations) |
| Friday | Easy run 45 min | Easy run 45 min + strides |
| Saturday | Long run 80 min | Long run 75 min |
| Sunday | Rest | Rest |

You go from 6 Zone 2 sessions to 3 Zone 2 + 1 threshold + 1 interval + 1 HIIT. Total running volume stays similar, but the intensity distribution shifts to 80/20. Within 4-6 weeks, your race-pace running will transform because your VO2max ceiling will lift and your lactate threshold will rise, making race pace a smaller fraction of your maximum capacity.

Zone 2 built the engine. Now you need to tune it for speed.

**Understanding the lactate challenge from the data:**
- Stations average 8.5 mmol/L — that's well above lactate threshold (~4 mmol/L for most athletes). Your muscles are producing lactate faster than clearance at every station.
- Running averages 7.7 mmol/L — still above threshold, which means you're NOT fully clearing lactate during runs. It's accumulating across the race.
- 79.5% of time above 80% HRmax — this is primarily glycolytic work, burning through glycogen stores rapidly.

**Three nutritional strategies that directly address lactate buffering:**

**1. Carb loading (3 days pre-race) — maximizing glycogen stores:**

Why it matters for lactate: Glycogen is the primary fuel for the glycolytic system that produces lactate. When glycogen stores are full, your muscles have maximum substrate availability. When glycogen depletes, you slow down — which doesn't reduce lactate production but DOES reduce your ability to maintain pace.

- Days 3, 2, 1 before race: 8-12 g/kg carbs per day = 656-984g for an 82kg athlete
- Focus on high-GI sources: white rice, pasta, bread, potatoes, sports drinks, fruit
- Reduce fiber intake to prevent GI distress on race day
- Reduce fat to make room for carbs in your caloric budget
- Your weight will increase 1-2kg — this is glycogen + water, not fat. Every gram of glycogen binds 3g of water. This water is beneficial for maintaining hydration.

**2. Sodium bicarbonate (race morning) — direct lactate buffer:**

Sodium bicarbonate is an alkaline buffer that increases blood pH, allowing your body to tolerate higher lactate levels before performance degrades. Given the sustained 8.5 mmol/L demands during stations, this has direct application.

- Dose: 0.2-0.3 g/kg = 16-25g for an 82kg athlete
- Timing: divided into 3-4 doses over 60-120 minutes pre-race, taken with a carb-rich meal
- CRITICAL: You MUST have trialled this in training at least 3-4 times. GI distress (nausea, cramping, diarrhea) is very common. Some athletes can tolerate it, others can't. If you haven't tested it, do NOT debut it on race day.
- Take with carbs and moderate water — this reduces GI side effects significantly.

**3. Beta-alanine loading (4+ weeks pre-race) — intracellular buffer:**

Beta-alanine increases muscle carnosine, which buffers hydrogen ions INSIDE the muscle cell. This is complementary to sodium bicarbonate, which buffers in the blood. Together they provide two layers of buffering.

- Dose: 3.2-6.4g/day for minimum 4 weeks (you need to start NOW if you haven't already)
- It doesn't have an acute effect — the benefit comes from chronic loading
- The Brandt data showing 2-3 minute station durations is exactly the sweet spot for beta-alanine's benefit (meta-analyses show best results for 1-10 minute high-intensity efforts)

**Race morning protocol for maximum lactate buffering:**

| Timing | What | Dose | Purpose |
|---|---|---|---|
| 3-4 hours pre | Large carb meal + sodium bicarb dose 1 | 100-150g carbs + 8g bicarb | Glycogen top-up + start buffering |
| 2-3 hours pre | Sodium bicarb dose 2 with water + small snack | 8g bicarb + 40g carbs | Continue buffering |
| 60-90 min pre | Caffeine + sodium bicarb dose 3 | 250-300mg caffeine + 8g bicarb | Perceived exertion reduction + final buffer dose |
| 30 min pre | Gel + beetroot shot | 25g carbs + 140ml beetroot juice | Blood glucose + vasodilation |

Absolutely NOT. What you're feeling is completely normal during a taper — in fact, it's a good sign. Let me explain the physiology so you stop panicking and trust the process.

**Why you feel terrible right now:**

The taper paradox is real and well-documented in sports science. When you reduce training volume by 20-30%, several things happen simultaneously:

1. **Glycogen supercompensation begins.** Your muscles are storing more glycogen than usual because you're consuming the same (or more) carbs but burning less. Glycogen binds water at a 1:3 ratio, making your legs feel heavy and swollen. This is FUEL being stored for race day. It's a good thing.

2. **Reduced endorphin production.** High-volume training produces endorphins that mask fatigue and improve mood. When volume drops, you lose that chemical buffer. Easy runs feel harder because the perceived exertion isn't being dampened by training-induced endorphins. Your ACTUAL fitness is fine.

3. **Psychological withdrawal.** You've been training 10+ hours per week for 13 weeks. Your brain is addicted to the training stimulus. Reducing it creates anxiety, restlessness, and the irrational belief that you're getting weaker. This is mental, not physical.

4. **Inflammatory clearance.** Your body is finally clearing the chronic low-grade inflammation from 13 weeks of heavy training. This healing process can temporarily make you feel achy, sluggish, or "off." It's your body repairing micro-damage that accumulated during training.

**The science of what's actually happening to your fitness:**

- Mujika & Padilla (2003) showed that a 2-3 week taper preserves (or slightly improves) VO2max while allowing muscular recovery.
- Performance typically improves 2-6% during a well-executed taper.
- Fitness markers (VO2max, lactate threshold, running economy) are NOT lost in 2-3 weeks of reduced volume. It takes 4-6 weeks of complete detraining before measurable fitness loss occurs.
- What IS lost in 2-3 weeks without maintenance: some blood plasma volume (recoverable within 48 hours of racing) and some neuromuscular sharpness (maintained by strides and short sharp efforts).

| Week | Running | HIIT | Strength | Key Sessions |
|---|---|---|---|---|

- Do NOT cut calories. If anything, slightly increase: +100-200 kcal above maintenance.
- Carbs at 6-7 g/kg through Week 15, then bump to 8-12 g/kg for the final 3 days pre-race.

**Principle 1: Fast-twitch creates fatigue, slow-twitch clears it.**

The sled push at 152kg recruits massive fast-twitch fiber activation — you're generating maximal force for 2-3 minutes. Blood lactate spikes to 7-8+ mmol/L. When you finish, your fast-twitch fibers are flooded with lactate and hydrogen ions. Your slow-twitch fibers are the clearance system — they consume lactate as fuel through the lactate shuttle.

But here's the problem: if you stand at the sled gasping, your slow-twitch fibers aren't being recruited enough to clear the lactate efficiently. They need movement — even slow movement — to activate the clearance mechanism.

**Application:** The INSTANT you finish sled push, START MOVING. Walk briskly through the Roxzone toward the running track. Don't stand. Don't bend over. Don't put hands on knees. Movement = clearance. Stillness = accumulation.

**Principle 2: Train both fiber types.**

Most Hyrox athletes train sled push as a pure power/strength exercise — heavy sets with full recovery. That only trains the fast-twitch component. Hinshaw would say you're leaving 50% of your capacity passive.

The training fix: 2x per week, do sled push intervals with ACTIVE RECOVERY between sets:
- 4 x 50m sled push at race weight (152kg)
- Between each set: 200m slow jog (NOT standing rest)
- The jog activates your slow-twitch fibers to begin clearing lactate immediately
- This is fundamentally different from 4 x 50m sled push with 3 min standing rest

After 3-4 weeks of this, your body learns to begin lactate clearance the moment the sled push ends — which is exactly what happens on race day when Run 3 starts.

**Principle 3: Pacing is the ultimate competitive advantage.**

Here's where most athletes destroy their sled push → Run 3 → sled pull sequence: they sprint the sled push, crawl through Run 3, and then hit the sled pull already depleted.

The Hinshaw pacing approach to this sequence:

| Segment | Pacing Strategy | Why |
|---|---|---|
| **Sled Push (50m)** | 90% effort, even splits across all 4 x 12.5m lengths | Going 100% on length 1 means lengths 3-4 slow dramatically. The total time at 90% effort is often FASTER than 100% effort because you don't decelerate. |
| **Roxzone → Run 3 start** | Immediate brisk walk → transition to slow jog within 15 sec | Active recovery begins NOW. Don't waste Roxzone time standing still. |
| **Run 3 (0-200m)** | Slow jog at ~5:30/km | Deliberate slow start. Slow-twitch fibers are consuming lactate. HR is settling from 90%+ to ~82-85% HRmax. |
| **Run 3 (200-500m)** | Build to moderate: ~4:50/km | Metabolic transition is happening. Breathing stabilizes. |
| **Run 3 (500-1000m)** | Race pace: 4:30-4:45/km | Lactate has cleared enough to sustain aerobic output. |
| **Roxzone → Sled Pull** | Maintain jog through Roxzone. Chalk hands while moving. | Keep blood flowing. Don't stop. |
| **Sled Pull (50m)** | 85% effort, controlled hand-over-hand rhythm | You're still carrying some lactate from the sled push. Going 100% here with elevated baseline lactate will produce a Run 4 that's even worse than Run 3. |

**Principle 4: Long-term cellular adaptation beats short-term intensity spikes.**

You won't fix the sled push → Run 3 → sled pull problem in 2 weeks. The adaptations you need — increased MCT1 lactate transporters, enhanced mitochondrial density in slow-twitch fibers, improved capillarization — take 8-12 weeks of consistent training.

**The 8-week training protocol for this specific sequence:**

- **Weeks 1-4:** 2x/week: Sled push 50m at 80% race weight → 800m run at moderate pace → Sled pull 50m at 80% race weight. 3 rounds, 3 min rest between rounds. Focus on active transitions.

- **Weeks 5-8:** 2x/week: Sled push 50m at 100% race weight → 1km run at goal race pace → Sled pull 50m at 100% race weight. 3 rounds, 2 min rest. Track Run splits — variance of <5 sec between rounds = excellent pacing.

**The result:** By race day, the sled push → Run 3 → sled pull sequence is no longer your weakness. It's where your Hinshaw-trained slow-twitch clearance system gives you an advantage over athletes who only trained heavy and fast.

Outside right knee pain during lunges and after long runs is a classic presentation of IT band syndrome (iliotibial band friction syndrome). I'm not a doctor and you need to get this assessed by a sports physiotherapist, but I can give you coaching guidance on how to manage training while addressing it.

**Why this is happening — the multi-factor analysis:**

1. **Sandbag lunges at 20kg Pro weight for 100m** require approximately 100-110 steps with significant knee flexion under load. Each step creates repeated friction of the IT band over the lateral femoral condyle (the bony prominence on the outside of your knee). At 65kg bodyweight with a 20kg sandbag, that's 85kg of total load on each single-leg stance.

2. **Long runs (10+ miles)** create thousands of knee flexion-extension cycles. If your hip abductors (glute medius) are weak or fatigued, your knee collapses inward on each stride (valgus), which increases IT band tension. This is common in athletes who've recently added significant running volume.

3. **You're in Week 6 — Specific Prep phase.** Volume and intensity are increasing simultaneously. Running is at 38 mpw, HIIT is at 3 sessions/week. This is the peak loading phase before the first deload at Week 8. Your connective tissue is under maximum training stress.

**Immediate management (this week):**

1. **Modify, don't stop.** Complete rest often makes IT band issues worse because the tissue deconditions. Instead:
   - Replace sandbag lunges with reverse lunges (step backward instead of forward). This reduces IT band friction while maintaining quad/glute training.
   - Reduce lunge distance to 50m at 10kg sandbag. Half the load, half the distance.
   - Shorten long runs to 60-70% of planned distance. If Saturday was 11 miles, do 7-8.
   - Keep easy runs if pain-free. If outside knee hurts during easy runs, switch to cycling or rowing for Zone 2 work.

2. **Daily rehab protocol (15 min, non-negotiable):**
   - Foam roll IT band and quads: 90 sec per side. Note: foam rolling doesn't "loosen" the IT band (it's too tough), but it reduces neural pain sensitivity and improves blood flow.
   - Side-lying clamshells: 3 x 15 per side with resistance band. Targets glute medius.
   - Single-leg Romanian deadlift: 3 x 10 per side with bodyweight or light dumbbell. Strengthens hip stabilizers.
   - Side-lying hip abduction: 3 x 15 per side.
   - Purpose: weak hip abductors are the root cause in 70%+ of IT band cases. Strengthen them and the knee pain resolves.

3. **Consider collagen supplementation:** Shaw et al. (2017) showed that 10-15g collagen peptides + 50mg Vitamin C taken 30-60 minutes before rehab exercise may support tendon and connective tissue repair. The evidence is early but the risk is essentially zero.

4. **Ice after training sessions if painful:** 10-15 min ice pack on the outside of the knee. This is one of the few times I recommend CWI for a specific injury, not general recovery.

**Periodization adjustment:**

Your Week 8 deload is 2 weeks away. If the knee responds well to the modified protocol above, you can return to full lunge training at Week 9. If it's still problematic at Week 8:
- Extend the deload to 10 days instead of 7
- Replace lunges with step-ups (lower IT band stress) through Week 10
- Only return to full race-distance lunges (100m at 20kg) if pain-free

**Nutrition for tissue healing:**
- Protein at 2.2 g/kg (143g/day for 65kg) — top of range to support tissue repair
- Omega-3s at 2-3g EPA/DHA daily — anti-inflammatory support
- Vitamin C from food (citrus, bell peppers) plus the collagen-paired dose
- Avoid NSAIDs (ibuprofen) as a routine solution — chronic use impairs tendon healing and collagen synthesis

**The line I won't let you cross:** If the pain worsens during a session, STOP that session. Don't push through sharp, worsening knee pain. Modified training preserves fitness. An injury that sidelines you for 4-6 weeks destroys it.

Get to a sports physio this week. Continue modified training in the meantime.

I just discovered I'll be racing in a venue that's notoriously hot and humid — like 28°C inside with high humidity. My race is in 5 weeks. How do I prepare?

Five weeks is tight but enough for meaningful heat acclimation. Hot, humid Hyrox venues are a real performance killer — every 1°C increase in core temperature above optimal reduces endurance performance by roughly 1-2%. In a venue at 28°C with high humidity, your core temperature will rise faster, sweat rate increases, and glycogen depletion accelerates. Here's the integrated preparation plan.

**The physiology of heat stress during Hyrox:**

- Heart rate increases 5-10 bpm at any given pace in heat versus cool conditions (cardiac drift)
- Sweat rate increases to 1.5-2.5 L/hr (vs 0.5-1.5 in cool conditions)
- Glycogen utilization increases ~8-10% in heat
- Blood is diverted from working muscles to the skin for cooling, reducing VO2max by 5-8%
- Perceived exertion increases at any given intensity

**Five-week heat acclimation protocol:**

**Weeks 1-3: Passive and active heat exposure**

- **Sauna sessions (3x/week, after easy runs):** 15-20 min at 80-100°C. This triggers plasma volume expansion — more blood volume means better heat dissipation AND better performance at any temperature. Start at 10 min if you're not used to sauna.
- **One run per week in warm conditions:** If possible, run during the hottest part of the day. Wear an extra layer for the first 2-3 weeks to simulate heat stress. Keep these runs at Zone 2 — don't add intensity stress on top of heat stress.
- **Hydration practice:** Begin tracking your sweat rate in warm conditions (weigh before and after exercise). Know your personal sweat rate so you can plan race-day hydration.

**Weeks 4-5: Race-specific heat preparation**

- **HIIT sessions in warm environments:** If your gym allows, train in the warmest conditions available. Wear a long-sleeve compression top during station work. This teaches your body to perform at race intensity in heat.
- **Practice your cooling strategy:** Mid-session, practice putting ice towels on the back of your neck or cold water on your wrists. These are the most effective rapid-cooling locations.

**Heat acclimation adaptations (what you gain in 5 weeks):**

| Adaptation | Timeline | Benefit |
|---|---|---|
| Reduced resting core temperature | 3-5 days | You start cooler, giving more thermal headroom |
| Earlier onset of sweating | 3-5 days | You start cooling sooner |
| Increased sweat rate | 5-10 days | More cooling capacity |
| Reduced sodium in sweat | 7-14 days | Better electrolyte retention |
| Expanded plasma volume | 7-14 days | Better cardiac output in heat |
| Reduced HR at given intensity | 10-14 days | More cardiovascular efficiency |
| Improved thermoregulation | 14-21 days | Lower core temp at race intensity |

Five weeks gives you time for ALL of these adaptations if you're consistent.

**Race-day nutrition adjustments for heat:**

1. **Pre-load sodium:** Starting 2 days before the race, increase sodium intake by 1,000-1,500mg per day (extra salt on food, electrolyte drinks). This expands plasma volume further and helps retain fluid.

2. **Pre-race hydration:** Drink 5-7 ml/kg of fluid 2-4 hours before with 500-750mg sodium. You should start the race fully hydrated with urine that's pale straw color.

3. **Increase intra-race carbs:** Heat increases glycogen utilization. Bump your intra-race intake from 30-60g/hr to 45-75g/hr. An extra gel (25-30g) beyond your normal race plan.

4. **Electrolyte drink, not plain water:** Every fluid intake during the race should contain 300-800mg sodium per liter. Plain water in hot conditions dilutes your blood sodium and can cause hyponatremia.

5. **Pre-cool:** In the warm-up area, use a cold towel on the back of your neck and drink an ice slurry (frozen sports drink) 30 min before start. This lowers your starting core temperature, giving you more thermal headroom before hitting the danger zone.

**Pacing adjustment for heat:**

Drop your target run pace by 10-15 seconds per km in hot conditions. If your normal target is 4:40/km, race at 4:50-4:55/km. This is not sandbagging — it's smart pacing that accounts for the increased cardiovascular and thermoregulatory demand. Athletes who ignore heat and pace to their cool-weather targets blow up spectacularly in the second half.

Bringing it all together: the sauna adaptation starts this week, the nutrition planning starts next week, and the race-day heat strategy gets practiced in your Week 3-4 simulation. Five weeks is enough to meaningfully improve your heat tolerance — but only if you start today.

I'm 45 years old and worried about recovery between my double-day sessions. Is there anything I should do differently compared to a 25-year-old athlete?

Age-related recovery differences are real, scientifically documented, and require specific adjustments. At 45, you're not "too old" for Hyrox — but you need a smarter approach than a 25-year-old. Here's what changes and what stays the same.

**What's physiologically different at 45:**

1. **Muscle protein synthesis (MPS) response is blunted.** The post-exercise MPS window is shorter and the magnitude is lower compared to younger athletes. This is called "anabolic resistance." It doesn't mean you can't build or maintain muscle — it means you need higher protein doses per meal to trigger the same response.

2. **Recovery rate is slower.** Hormonal changes (lower testosterone, higher cortisol at baseline) mean tissue repair takes 10-20% longer. A 25-year-old might recover from a hard HIIT session in 36 hours; you may need 48-60 hours.

3. **Connective tissue is less resilient.** Tendons, ligaments, and cartilage lose elasticity with age. High-impact, high-volume training increases injury risk — particularly in the knees, Achilles, and shoulders.

4. **Sleep quality typically declines.** Melatonin production decreases, deep sleep percentage often drops, and sleep efficiency decreases. Since deep sleep is where growth hormone is released and tissue repair peaks, this compounds the recovery problem.

5. **VO2max declines ~1% per year after age 25 without intervention.** But this is largely reversible with training — masters athletes who maintain high training volumes lose only 0.5% per year.

**Training modifications for a 45-year-old Hyrox athlete:**

| Variable | 25-Year-Old | 45-Year-Old Adjustment |
|---|---|---|
| Weekly training days | 6 | **5** (or 6 with one being very light active recovery) |
| Double days per week | 2-3 | **1-2 max** (separate by 8+ hours, not 6) |
| Hard session frequency | 3-4 per week | **2-3 per week** (never 2 hard days in a row) |
| Deload frequency | Every 4th week | **Every 3rd week** (3 weeks on, 1 week deload) |
| Running volume | 35-40 mpw | **30-35 mpw** (same quality, slightly less volume) |
| Strength volume | 4 sets per exercise | **3 sets** (maintain intensity, reduce volume) |
| Impact management | Standard | Replace 1 easy road run per week with cycling or pool running |

**Nutrition modifications — these are critical:**

1. **Protein: 2.2-2.4 g/kg/day** (higher than the 1.8-2.0 recommended for younger athletes). The anabolic resistance means you need more leucine per meal to trigger MPS. Target 35-45g protein per meal across 4-5 meals, with emphasis on leucine-rich sources (whey, eggs, dairy, chicken).

2. **Pre-sleep protein is more important.** Casein or cottage cheese (30-40g) before bed gives your body amino acids during the longer recovery window you need. For a 45-year-old, this isn't optional — it's a significant recovery lever.

3. **Omega-3s: 2-3g EPA/DHA daily.** Chronic low-grade inflammation increases with age. Omega-3s help manage this without the adaptation-blunting effects of NSAIDs.

4. **Vitamin D: 3,000-4,000 IU/day.** Vitamin D status typically worsens with age due to reduced skin synthesis. Maintain serum levels at ≥40 ng/ml. Get tested annually.

5. **Collagen peptides: 10-15g + 50mg Vitamin C, 30-60 min before training.** Your connective tissue needs more support. The evidence is early but the cost-benefit ratio is favorable for a 45-year-old doing high-impact Hyrox training.

**Sleep optimization becomes your #1 recovery tool:**

- Target 8.5-9 hours in bed (to achieve 7.5-8 hours of actual sleep)
- Magnesium glycinate 400mg before bed
- Bedroom at 18-19°C
- No caffeine after noon (your caffeine metabolism likely slows with age)
- Consider a 20-min nap on double-day training days between sessions

**The good news:**

Hyrox actually favors masters athletes more than many sports because it rewards endurance, pacing discipline, and experience over raw speed and power. Your aerobic base, built over 20+ years of training, is a massive advantage. The sled push doesn't care how old you are — it cares how strong and well-paced you are.

The 45-year-old who trains smart, recovers fully, and eats enough protein will outperform the 25-year-old who trains recklessly, sleeps 6 hours, and under-eats. Age is a variable, not a limitation.

My training partner and I do most sessions together but he's way stronger and I'm way faster. We're doing Hyrox Doubles. How should we split station work and what should our individual training focus on?

This is actually an ideal Doubles pairing — complementary strengths, not overlapping ones. The key is leveraging each person's advantage while mitigating weaknesses. Let me design both the race strategy and the individual training plans.

**Race-day station splitting strategy:**

Assuming Partner A (you) = faster runner, weaker at heavy stations. Partner B = slower runner, stronger at heavy stations.

| Station | Total Volume | You (Runner) | Partner B (Strongman) | Why |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| SkiErg | 2,000m | 1,200m | 800m | You have better aerobic pacing for sustained erg work |
| Sled Push | 8 x 12.5m | 3 lengths | 5 lengths | He's stronger; let him carry the heavy sled work |
| Sled Pull | 8 x 12.5m | 3 lengths | 5 lengths | Same — his pulling strength is the advantage |
| BBJ | 160m | 100m | 60m | You're more efficient at bodyweight explosive work |
| Rowing | 2,000m | 1,200m | 800m | Your aerobic engine handles sustained erg better |
| Farmers Carry | 400m | 150m | 250m | His grip endurance is likely better at heavy loads |
| Sandbag Lunges | 200m | 120m | 80m | You split lunges toward your quad endurance |
| Wall Balls | 200 reps | 120 reps | 80 reps | You take more reps — this is muscular endurance, not max strength |

**The running complication:**
You MUST run together — you can't separate by more than a certain distance without penalty (1-min penalty per run, DQ after 3rd infringement). This means YOU set the pace, not him. Run at HIS comfortable tempo effort, which might feel easy for you. That's actually a benefit — you're running at a lower relative intensity, which means you arrive at stations fresher than in a Singles race.

**Individual training focus (remaining 8+ weeks):**

**Your training (the runner):**

Your running is already strong. Focus training time on your weak stations:

1. **Wall ball endurance:** You're taking 120 reps. Build to 120-rep sets in training: start with EMOM 20 at 12 reps/min = 240 reps. Progress to 15/min.
2. **Lunge endurance:** Build to 120m unbroken at 20kg.
3. **BBJ volume:** Build to 100m in training (you're covering 100m on race day).
4. **Running with partner:** 2 runs/week together at his pace. Practice conversation during runs — this is how Doubles partners communicate strategy mid-race.

Maintain your running fitness with your solo sessions at your normal paces.

**Partner B's training (the strongman):**

His strength is adequate. His weak link is aerobic capacity:

1. **Running volume:** Add 2-3 Zone 2 runs per week at 8:00-9:00/mi. His running doesn't need to be fast — it needs to be sustainable for 8km. If he can hold 5:30/km for all 8 runs, that's sufficient.
2. **Erg conditioning:** Even though he's taking less erg volume, he still needs to complete 800m of SkiErg and 800m of rowing efficiently. 2 erg sessions/week with pacing focus.
3. **Sled endurance at race weight:** 8 x 12.5m instead of 4. He needs to handle the doubled sled volume without destroying his legs for subsequent runs.
4. **Recovery between stations:** He needs to learn the Hinshaw active recovery principle — keep moving between his station sets. When he finishes his 5 sled push lengths and hands off to you, he should be walking/jogging, not standing still.

**Nutrition for Doubles:**

- Both athletes carry their own fueling. Coordinate gel timing so you're not both trying to eat during the same Roxzone transition.
- The partner doing more station work (Partner B) will deplete glycogen faster — he should take an extra gel between Stations 3 and 5.
- Hydration: carry separate soft flasks. Take turns drinking during runs to avoid slowing each other down.

**Practice together at least 30% of sessions in the final 8 weeks:**
- Full Doubles simulation at least 2x before race day
- Time each partner's station contributions separately
- Adjust the split based on real data, not assumptions
- Practice handoffs until they're automatic — "GO" signal, immediate transition, zero wasted seconds

Your complementary skill sets are a massive advantage in Doubles. A team of two average athletes will beat a team of two specialists because Doubles punishes weaknesses harder than it rewards strengths. The runner who can also do 120 wall balls + the strongman who can also sustain 8km of running = a competitive Doubles team.

I have access to a Concept2 SkiErg and rower but no sleds. What's the best sled substitute for training, and how do I make sure I'm ready for race-day sled weight?

No sled access is a common problem, and it's solvable. But I want to be upfront: there is NO perfect substitute for sled push/pull at race weight. The sled push is a unique movement — full-body horizontal force production with ground friction dynamics that no gym exercise replicates exactly. So your strategy needs two parts: best possible substitutes AND a plan to get sled exposure before race day.

**Part 1: Sled Push Substitutes**

| Exercise | How It Transfers | What It Misses |
|---|---|---|
| **Heavy prowler/car push** | Best substitute if available. Same horizontal force pattern, similar body angle. | Different friction coefficient than Hyrox sled on turf. |
| **Treadmill push (powered off)** | Decent force production pattern. Set treadmill to OFF (not powered), lean in, and push the belt with your legs. | Less resistance than a 152kg sled. |
| **Heavy wall pushes (isometric)** | Trains the leg drive angle and bracing pattern. Lean into a wall at 45 degrees and drive legs as hard as possible, 10 sec holds x 10. | No movement — isometric only. |
| **Heavy barbell walking lunges** | Trains the quad/glute endurance and single-leg drive pattern. 4 x 25m @ heavy load. | No horizontal force vector. |
| **Leg press (high rep)** | Mimics the quad force production at similar knee angles. 3 x 20 @ heavy weight. | No core bracing, no ground contact. |

**My recommended sled push substitute protocol (2-3x/week):**

1. **Primary:** Heavy lunges or heavy prowler (if available): 4 x 50m at the heaviest load you can maintain for the full 50m. Rest 3 min. This builds the specific muscular endurance needed.
2. **Secondary:** Isometric wall drives: 8 x 10 sec at max effort with 20 sec rest. This trains the force production angle.
3. **Tertiary:** Leg press 3 x 20 at 2x bodyweight. Builds raw quad endurance.

**Part 1B: Sled Pull Substitutes**

| Exercise | Transfer | Misses |
|---|---|---|
| **Heavy cable rows (seated)** | Pulling pattern, grip endurance. | No hip extension/full body component. |
| **Hand-over-hand rope pull (cable machine)** | Closest gym substitute. Thread a rope through a cable stack, pull hand-over-hand while anchoring with your feet. | Different friction and rope feel. |
| **Heavy barbell bent-over rows** | Posterior chain, grip endurance. | Bilateral, not the hand-over-hand pattern. |
| **Farmers walk** | Grip endurance, loaded locomotion. | Different pulling mechanics. |

**Recommended pull substitute protocol:**
1. Hand-over-hand cable pulls: 4 x 12.5m (simulate one race length per set). Heavy. Rest 90 sec.
2. Bent-over row: 3 x 8 @ 80% 1RM. Grip work.
3. Dead hangs after every pull session: 3 x max hold. Grip endurance.

**Part 2: Getting sled exposure before race day — this is non-negotiable**

You MUST push and pull a competition sled at race weight before race day. The movement pattern, friction, and pacing are too unique to walk in blind. Options:

1. **Hyrox Pop-Up events:** Hyrox runs pop-up simulation events in many cities. Check the Hyrox website for events near you. These give you the exact race sleds on race-surface turf.
2. **CrossFit gyms or functional fitness facilities:** Many have sleds. Pay a day-pass rate and spend 60 minutes doing sled work. Call ahead to confirm they have a sled that can load to 152kg.
3. **Strength and conditioning facilities:** University gyms, PT studios, and specialist strength gyms often have heavy sleds.
4. **Hyrox training facilities (HYROX24):** Hyrox-branded gym facilities exist in some cities with exact race equipment.

**Minimum sled exposure plan:**
- Get to a sled at least 4 times before race day
- Session 1 (8-10 weeks out): Technique at 80% race weight. Learn body angle, step cadence, pull rhythm.
- Session 2 (6-8 weeks out): Race weight, full 50m push + 50m pull. Time it.
- Session 3 (3-4 weeks out): Full simulation context — run 1km, sled push, run 1km, sled pull. At race weight.
- Session 4 (1-2 weeks out): Light rehearsal — 2 x 25m push/pull at race weight. Don't fatigue, just refresh the motor pattern.

**Energy system consideration:**
The sled push is 2-3 minutes of phosphagen + glycolytic work. Your substitute exercises need to replicate this time domain and intensity. Don't do sets of 5 heavy squats as a substitute — do sets of 20 lunges that take 60-90 seconds. The metabolic stimulus matters as much as the movement pattern.

Substitutes build 80% of the fitness. The sled sessions build the remaining 20% — the technique, pacing, and confidence you can't get any other way.

I bonked hard at my last race — I was on pace for sub-1:20 through the first 5 stations but my last 3 runs were 30-45 seconds slower each and wall balls took me over 6 minutes. What went wrong and how do I fix it for next time?

Classic second-half collapse. You were on pace for a great time and then everything fell apart. Let me do a root cause analysis — this is almost certainly a combination of pacing error, fueling failure, and inadequate simulation training.

**Root Cause 1: Aggressive first-half pacing (most likely primary cause)**

If your first 5 runs were at sub-4:30/km pace and your stations were fast, you were running above sustainable intensity for the full race duration. Brandt et al. (2025) shows that 79.5% of Hyrox race time is spent above 80% HRmax. If you were at 88-90% HRmax for the first half, you've burned through glycogen at an accelerated rate and accumulated a lactate debt you can never fully repay.

The math: at 90% HRmax, glycogen burn rate is approximately 3-4g per minute. Over the first 40 minutes, that's 120-160g of glycogen — roughly 30-40% of your total stores. Without adequate replenishment, you hit the wall at Station 6-7.

**Evidence check:** Were your first 5 runs faster than your training paces? Were your first 3 station times faster than your simulation benchmarks? If yes, you went out too fast.

**Root Cause 2: Inadequate intra-race fueling**

What did you eat and drink during the race? Most athletes who bonk at wall balls took zero or one gel during the race. For a sub-1:20 pace (75-80 minutes), you need 30-60g of carbohydrate per hour — that's 40-80g total. If you took nothing, your blood glucose crashed alongside your glycogen stores.

**The fix for fueling:**
- Gel 1: After Station 2 (sled push), during Run 3 — 25g carbs
- Gel 2: After Station 5 (rowing), during Run 6 — 25g carbs
- Sip of electrolyte drink at every available aid station
- Total intra-race carbs: 50-65g. This should be non-negotiable.

**Root Cause 3: Insufficient simulation training**

Did you ever complete a full race simulation at race weight and race pace during training? If your longest simulation was 6 stations or 60 minutes, you never trained your body to sustain effort at the 70-80 minute mark. The physical and metabolic demands of minutes 65-80 are drastically different from minutes 1-40 due to cumulative glycogen depletion, lactate accumulation, and neuromuscular fatigue.

**Root Cause 4: Pre-race carb loading may have been insufficient**

Full glycogen stores hold ~400-500g of glycogen (~1,600-2,000 kcal of readily available fuel). If you didn't carb-load properly (8-12 g/kg for 2-3 days pre-race), you may have started with partially filled stores. Combined with aggressive pacing and poor intra-race fueling, the tank ran dry at Station 6.

**The comprehensive fix for your next race:**

**Training (next 12-16 week block):**
1. Complete at least 3 full race simulations (not half-sims, FULL). Time every station and every run.
2. Practice negative-split pacing: deliberately run the first 4 runs 10-15 sec/km slower than your target average. Speed up in runs 5-8.
3. Train wall balls in a fatigued state: always do wall balls LAST in simulation sessions, after lunges and a run. This is the race sequence.
4. Add one 90-minute Zone 2 session per week to build the metabolic endurance for the full race duration.

**Nutrition (race preparation):**
1. **3 days pre-race:** Carb load at 8-12 g/kg. For an 82kg athlete, that's 656-984g of carbs per day. Yes, it's a lot. Eat it.
2. **Race morning:** 1-4 g/kg carbs 3-4 hours before. 60-80g 90 min before.
3. **During race:** 2 gels minimum, plus electrolyte drink. Practice this exact protocol in your simulations.
4. **Caffeine:** 3-4 mg/kg, 60-90 minutes pre-race. Reduces perceived exertion by 5-6%.

**Pacing (race execution):**

| Run | Old Strategy (failed) | New Strategy |
|---|---|---|
| Runs 1-3 | Sub-4:30/km (too fast) | 4:40-4:50/km (controlled) |
| Runs 4-5 | 4:30-4:40/km | 4:40-4:45/km |
| Runs 6-7 | 5:00-5:15/km (blowing up) | 4:35-4:45/km (consistent) |
| Run 8 | 5:30+/km (survival mode) | 4:30-4:40/km (strong finish) |

The new strategy sacrifices 10-15 seconds per km in the first half but saves 30-45 seconds per km in the second half. Net gain: 2-4 minutes faster overall. And your wall balls go from 6:00+ (depleted) to 3:45-4:15 (fueled and paced correctly).

**The lesson:** Hyrox races are won in the second half. The athlete who paces conservatively, fuels properly, and still has glycogen at Station 8 will ALWAYS beat the athlete who goes out fast and collapses. Your sub-1:20 is absolutely achievable — but it requires discipline in the first 40 minutes, not heroism.

What role does running economy play in Hyrox and how can I improve it without adding more miles?

Running economy — the oxygen cost of running at a given pace — is the unsung hero of Hyrox performance. Two athletes with identical VO2max values can have vastly different 5K times based on economy alone. And in Hyrox, where you run 8km with fatigued legs, economy matters even more because inefficiency compounds across every kilometer.

**Why running economy is especially important in Hyrox:**

1. **Fatigue amplifies inefficiency.** If you have a slight heel-striking pattern that costs 3% extra oxygen per stride, that 3% tax is manageable when fresh but devastating after a sled push when your VO2 is already at 85-90% of max. Better economy = more headroom when fatigued.

2. **You're running on compromised legs.** Post-station running involves altered biomechanics — shorter stride, higher ground contact time, more muscular braking forces. An economical runner adapts to these changes with less energy cost.

3. **Economy saves glycogen.** More economical running burns less glycogen per kilometer at a given pace, preserving fuel for stations. Over 8km, this could mean the difference between having glycogen for wall balls or bonking.

**How to improve economy WITHOUT adding miles:**

**1. Strides (4-6 x 100m, 2-3x/week, added to easy runs):**
Strides are 100m accelerations at mile pace with full walk-back recovery. They train your neuromuscular system to recruit motor units efficiently at higher speeds. The carryover to slower paces is significant — your muscles learn to fire more precisely, reducing wasted energy.
- Total added volume: 400-600m per session. Negligible mileage impact.
- Time cost: 8-10 minutes per session.
- Economy benefit: Research shows strides improve running economy by 2-4% over 6-8 weeks.

**2. Plyometrics (2x/week, 10 min, in warm-up):**
- Box jumps: 3 x 5 (focus on minimal ground contact, reactive landing)
- Single-leg hops: 3 x 10/leg
- Pogos (ankle bounces): 3 x 20
- These train your musculotendinous unit to store and return elastic energy — the "spring" in your stride. Better elastic energy return = less muscular work per stride = better economy.
- Keep total ground contacts under 80 per session to avoid overloading connective tissue.

**3. Cadence optimization:**
Most recreational runners overstride (cadence below 170 steps/min), which creates a braking force with each foot strike. Target 175-185 steps/min. Higher cadence = shorter ground contact time = less vertical oscillation = better economy.
- Use a metronome app during one easy run per week. Set it to your target cadence.
- Don't force it — increase by 5 spm per week until you reach 175+.

**4. Strength training (which you're already doing):**
Heavy squats and deadlifts improve running economy by 3-5% (Beattie et al., 2014 meta-analysis). The mechanism: stronger muscles produce more force per motor unit, requiring fewer total motor units per stride, reducing oxygen cost. Your existing strength program (3x4 squat at 80-85%) is already contributing to economy improvements.

**5. Hill sprints (1x/week, 6-8 reps):**
- Find a steep hill (8-12% grade). Sprint uphill for 10-12 seconds. Walk down. Repeat 6-8 times.
- Total time: 15 minutes. Total running distance: ~600-800m.
- These train explosive hip extension and powerful push-off — the exact force vectors that make efficient running.
- Bonus: hill sprints have minimal eccentric stress (no pounding), so they don't create the muscle damage that flat sprints do.

**The economy training schedule (integrated into your existing plan):**

| When | What | Added Time |
|---|---|---|
| Monday easy run | 4 x 100m strides at end | +8 min |
| Tuesday warm-up | Box jumps 3x5, pogos 3x20 | +10 min |
| Thursday warm-up | SL hops 3x10, pogos 3x20 | +10 min |
| Friday easy run | 4 x 100m strides at end | +8 min |
| Saturday AM | 6 x 10-sec hill sprints before long run | +15 min |

**Total added training time: ~51 minutes per week. Zero additional mileage.**

The economy improvements compound with your aerobic base and VO2max work. After 8 weeks, you'll notice the same pace feels easier — lower heart rate, lower RPE, less effort per stride. That saved effort translates directly to faster, more sustainable running across all 8 Hyrox kilometers.

What's the best way to build mental toughness specifically for the last 3 stations of Hyrox? That's where I always fall apart mentally.

Stations 6-8 (Farmers Carry, Sandbag Lunges, Wall Balls) are the mental crucible of Hyrox. By this point, you've been racing for 50-70 minutes, your glycogen is depleted, lactate has accumulated across 5 previous stations and 6 runs, and your brain is screaming at you to stop. Mental toughness here is NOT about willpower alone — it's about specific preparation that reduces the psychological shock of what your body is experiencing.

**Why you fall apart — the neuroscience:**

Perceived exertion is not just a physical phenomenon. Your brain integrates signals from multiple sources: metabolic stress (glycogen depletion, lactate), thermal stress (core temperature rise), cardiovascular stress (HR at 85-90% HRmax for 50+ minutes), and psychological stress (remaining workload, pain). When these signals converge, your brain downregulates motor output to protect you — this is the "Central Governor" model (Noakes, 2012).

The key insight: **your brain makes the quit decision before your muscles physically cannot continue.** You're not actually at muscular failure during Station 7 lunges — your brain is preemptively shutting you down because the composite stress signal is too high. Mental toughness training teaches your brain that these stress levels are survivable.

**Five strategies for Stations 6-8 mental toughness:**

**1. Simulation exposure (the most important strategy):**
Your brain panics at unfamiliar stress levels. The fix: make Stations 6-8 stress levels FAMILIAR through repeated practice.
- Every full and partial simulation must include all of Stations 6-8 IN THE RACE SEQUENCE: Run 6 → Farmers Carry → Run 7 → Sandbag Lunges → Run 8 → Wall Balls.
- Do this after completing at least 4 preceding stations so the fatigue is real.
- Minimum 3 full simulations before race day. After each one, Stations 6-8 feel less foreign to your nervous system.

**2. Process goals, not outcome goals:**
During Stations 6-8, your brain is fixating on how much is LEFT ("I have 60m more lunges... then wall balls... then the finish line..."). Shift to process focus:
- Farmers Carry: "Tall posture. Brisk steps. Don't look at the distance markers."
- Lunges: "Step... drive... step... drive..." Count every 10 steps. "That's 10. Now 10 more."
- Wall Balls: "Catch, squat, throw. Catch, squat, throw." Break it into micro-sets: "Just 25 more. That's all."

The process focus keeps your brain from catastrophizing about the remaining workload.

**3. Pre-committed break strategies:**
Deciding when to break DURING the station is mentally expensive — it requires cognitive effort at a time when your brain is depleted. Instead, pre-commit to a break strategy before the race:
- Farmers Carry: NO BREAKS. Non-negotiable. You've trained this.
- Lunges: 50m continuous, 5-sec pause, 50m continuous. OR 25-25-25-25 with 3-sec pauses.
- Wall Balls: 25-25-25-25 with 5-sec pauses. Start each set on a pre-determined breath count (3 breaths, then go).

Write these strategies on your arm. When your brain starts negotiating for an extra break, look at your arm and follow the plan.

**4. Segmentation and dissociation:**
- **Segmentation:** Break each station into small, manageable chunks. "I'm not doing 100m of lunges — I'm doing 4 x 25m."
- **Dissociation:** During the runs between Stations 6-8, redirect attention away from pain. Focus on external cues: the crowd, the music, counting your footsteps, maintaining cadence. Research shows that associative focus (monitoring body signals) is effective early in a race but dissociative strategies work better in the final quarter when pain is at its highest.

**5. Physiological preparation that reduces mental strain:**

The mental battle is EASIER when you're physically better prepared:
- **Fuel properly:** Take a gel during Run 6 (25g carbs). Low blood glucose directly impairs cognitive function and increases perceived exertion. Fueling your brain is literally fueling your toughness.
- **Caffeine:** If you took 200-300mg pre-race, the ergogenic effect is still active at Stations 6-8. Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, directly reducing perceived exertion. This is chemical mental toughness.
- **Pacing:** If you've conserved energy in the first half by running at controlled paces, you arrive at Station 6 with more physical AND mental reserves. Athletes who go out too fast don't just bonk physically — they bonk mentally because the composite stress signal maxes out earlier.

**Training protocol for mental toughness (integrate into HIIT sessions):**

- Once per week, do Stations 6-7-8 back-to-back-to-back after a 3km run. Full race weight. No scaling. This is practice suffering.
- During the session, practice your verbal cues out loud: "step, drive, step, drive" on lunges. "Catch, squat, throw" on wall balls. Talking through the movement occupies your brain and reduces the cognitive bandwidth available for negative self-talk.
- After the session, rate your mental performance separately from your physical performance. "Physically I was an 8, mentally I was a 6" — then focus on improving the mental score.

Mental toughness isn't a personality trait. It's a skill. And like every other skill in Hyrox, it responds to deliberate, specific practice.
